awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Investigation of the fate and transport of dust-borne trace metals and solutes during snowmelt
awd_abstract_narration:
Collaborative Research: Investigation of the fate of dust-borne trace metals and solutes during snowmelt

Abstract

Wind-blown dust contributes trace metals and soluble salts to mountain snowpack, with potential negative impacts on water quality during snowmelt. Sediment records from mountain lakes in the western U.S. suggest that dust deposition has increased five-fold over the past 150 years due to human disturbance of desert soils, with more dust expected in the future due to climate change. Little is known, however, concerning the impacts of dust on the chemistry of mountain streams. Snowmelt-fed streams are a primary source of drinking water in the western U.S. The Provo River is a prime example of this, supplying water to over 50% of the residents of Utah. This project investigates the effects of dust on water quality during snowmelt in the upper Provo River watershed in the Uinta Mountains. Assessment of dust contributions to mountain snowpack  and demonstration of pathways of trace metal and salt transport during snowmelt have the potential to extend across the Intermountain West and beyond the U.S. to other mountainous areas receiving substantial dust input, including the Andes, Himalayas, and European Alps. This project provides K-16 student outreach opportunities during inquiry-based field exercises, fosters cross-campus collaborations for graduate students at Utah's three major research institutions (University of Utah, Utah State University, and Brigham Young University), and broadens participation of underrepresented groups by involving women and minorities. 

The project investigates the fate and transport of dust-derived trace metals and solutes during snowmelt building from detailed field sampling and comprehensive analyses. Dust contributions to stream solute budgets during snowmelt are quantified with isotopic tracers (e.g., strontium, boron, sulfur, oxygen and hydrogen) and mixing analyses. The role of organic matter-facilitated trace-metal transport from snowpack to streams is examined through application of several novel analytical methods. Spatial heterogeneity in dust deposition is quantified, and the availability of trace metals in dust is characterized via sequential leaching experiments. The Provo River watershed is an ideal location for investigating impacts of dust on water chemistry because it is underlain by relatively simple siliciclastic bedrock that permits clear observations of exogenous dust and is well instrumented with atmospheric and aquatic monitoring stations from the Innovation Urban Transitions and Aridregion Hydro-sustainability (iUTAH) observatory funded by NSF. The geological setting and extensive instrumentation provide an unprecedented opportunity to explore the impacts of dust deposition on stream chemistry during snowmelt.

por.por_cntn:
Mountain snow and ice are crucial for the health of the biosphere, providing water to downstream ecosystems, agriculture and about two billion humans in our planet. These types of watersheds experience dramatic seasonal changes that regulate the rhythm of  life and anthropogenic usage in the area, with the highest flows attained during snowmelt in the spring. Alteration of timing, flow amount or water quality from background values due to climate change or land use may have deep consequences in the near future. In this project, we focus on the chemical components incorporated in a snow-fed watershed, the Provo River in Utah, and studied where and how they become part of the system and the mechanisms of transport and removal. We sampled dust in the snowpack, alpine soils, ephemeral streams, and Provo river water at the headwaters and two lower elevations downstream with minimal anthropogenic impacts over a 5-year period spanning years with below- and above-average discharge. Using analytical methodologies to measure the chemical elements contained in dust, soil and water, we determined that chemical components show different systematic behaviors: while the concentrations of the major elements and some trace elements in the river headwaters, like calcium, strontium or sulfate, are roughly constant year round, many trace elements, like lead and beryllium, and organic matter are added in their vast majority in relatively short pulses during spring run-off each year and progressively removed downstream. In contrast, major elements concentrations, while diluted during snowmelt, increase from upstream to downstream due to inputs from groundwater flowing through carbonate and volcanic rocks . Because trace element concentrations are relatively high in ephemeral streams and soil water and much lower in the snowpack, we conclude that flushing of shallow soils by snowmelt produces a surge of many trace element in the river headwaters and represents an important control on downstream water chemistry. In turn, atmospheric dust plays a key role in the formation of soils in this area over long times, and then indirectly in the river water chemistry. By collecting atmospheric dust at different places in Utah, we show that current dust deposition in the snowpack derives mostly from the large dry playas existing in the region, with some contribution of anthropogenic aerosols. In this way, regional dust contributes to the chemical composition of alpine streams with potential impacts on water quality. Contaminants reaching these alpine soils may therefore be incorporated in river water during snowmelt runoff, with implications for understanding how water diversions, land use changes, and population growth may affect the main water supply for Utah population.

Our project has provided training in the study of hydrological processes, trace elements and isotopic tracers in aquatic systems, and mass-spectrometry methodologies for six graduate students, six undergraduate students and one high-school student, including five female students, resulting in three master of science theses, five papers published in peer-reviewed journals, ten conference presentations, and two state science fair presentations. Our results were disseminated in local meetings and field trips of the Provo River Watershed Users Association, Provo River Watershed Council, Utah Division of Water Quality, American Water Works Association, iUTAH Annual Symposium, Great Salt Lake Technical Team meeting, and Utah Geological Association. Results from this project are being used to inform water managers and regulators in northern Utah.
